items.title: Harvard scientist defends alien probe theory despite new images

featured_image.name: Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS caught on camera in new ... - Space

items.description:
As interstellar visitor 3I/ATLAS speeds away from the inner solar system, Harvard astrophysicist Avi Loeb continues to argue the object exhibits too many anomalies to dismiss extraterrestrial origins, even as new telescope images debunk viral theories that it was deliberately hiding itself.

Fresh observations from the Hubble Space Telescope captured on December 12 and 27 reveal a stable double-jet structure streaming from the comet's nucleus, while separate imaging shows the object's outer coma is thinning naturally rather than through any intentional cloaking mechanism, according to International Business Times UK[1][2]. The object made its closest approach to Earth on December 19 at approximately 168 million miles, offering astronomers a final window to study the third confirmed interstellar visitor to our solar system[3][2].

items.title: Gold and silver post strongest gains since 1979

featured_image.name: Gold, silver head for biggest annual gains in over 40 years

items.description:
Gold and silver are poised to end 2025 with their most impressive annual gains in more than four decades, despite sharp late-December selloffs that underscored the extraordinary volatility in precious metals markets.

Gold climbed approximately 66% this year, while silver surged over 150%, according to multiple market sources[1][2][3][4]. Both metals are heading for their strongest yearly performance since 1979, when the Iranian Revolution and runaway inflation drove gold up 126%[1][5][6][7].

The year-end rally turned turbulent in late December when CME Group raised margin requirements on precious metals futures twice within a week[8][9][10]. The exchange cited "market volatility to ensure adequate collateral coverage" as silver broke above $80 per ounce for the first time and gold approached $4,550[8][11]. Silver margins jumped approximately 30%, while gold requirements rose roughly 9%, forcing traders to post additional cash during one of the year's thinnest trading periods[12][10].

Silver plunged nearly 9% on Monday, December 29, to just above $73 per ounce after briefly exceeding $84 over the weekend[13]. Gold dropped more than 4% to around $4,355[13]. Both metals staged recoveries on Tuesday before falling again Wednesday, with silver declining more than 8% and gold slipping approximately 0.75%[13][14].

items.title: Xi declares Taiwan reunification 'unstoppable'

featured_image.name: Xi reaffirms China's claim to Taiwan in New Year's address - Yahoo

items.description:
Chinese President Xi Jinping declared Wednesday that Taiwan's reunification with China is "unstoppable," capping off 2025 with a forceful message about the self-ruled island's future. In his annual New Year's Eve address, Xi said Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait share "a bond of blood and kinship," adding that "the reunification of our motherland, a trend of the times, is unstoppable"[1][2][3].

The remarks came one day after China's People's Liberation Army announced it had "successfully completed" Justice Mission 2025, a two-day military exercise that encircled Taiwan with warships, fighter jets, and missile forces[1][2][4]. Senior Captain Li Xi, spokesperson for the PLA's Eastern Theater Command, said the drills "fully tested the integrated joint operations capabilities" of Chinese troops[1][4].

items.title: Russia, Ukraine exchange strikes on power grids

featured_image.name: Why is Russia escalating attacks on Ukraine’s Odesa?

items.description:
Russian drone attacks on Ukraine's southern port city of Odesa left six people injured and more than 170,000 residents without electricity overnight December 30-31, while a major power outage struck Moscow's suburbs affecting over 100,000 people during the same period, according to local authorities and energy officials.

The Russian assault on Odesa damaged four apartment buildings and struck two energy facilities operated by DTEK, Ukraine's largest private power company, leaving parts of the city without electricity, water, and heating amid freezing temperatures[1][2][3][4]. Among the wounded were three children—ages seven months, eight, and 14—while a 42-year-old man remained in serious condition[5][2][6]. Firefighters rescued eight people from burning buildings as flames engulfed residential structures[4][7].

"Another proof that Russia is targeting civilians," Serhii Lysak, head of Odesa City Military Administration, wrote on social media[7]. The Ukrainian Energy Ministry reported that emergency repair work was underway, though restoration efforts have been hampered by the extent of damage to critical infrastructure[8][9][10].

items.title: Finland seizes cargo ship after undersea cables damaged

featured_image.name: Finland detains vessel after cables damaged between Tallinn ...

items.description:
Finnish authorities seized a cargo vessel on Wednesday after two telecommunications cables connecting Helsinki and Tallinn were damaged in the Gulf of Finland, marking the latest incident in a series of suspected sabotage attacks on critical Baltic Sea infrastructure.

The Finnish Border Guard intercepted the cargo ship Fitburg after telecoms provider Elisa detected a fault in one of its submarine cables early Wednesday morning[1][2]. The vessel, which departed Saint Petersburg on December 30 and was en route to Israel, was found operating with its anchor chain deployed in Finland's exclusive economic zone[1][2]. The actual damage to the cables occurred in Estonia's economic zone[1][3][2].

"Finland is prepared for a range of security challenges and will respond as required," President Alexander Stubb said in a statement on social media[1]. Prime Minister Petteri Orpo confirmed that state agencies are working together to determine the cause and extent of the damage[1].

The Fitburg, flying the flag of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, was ordered to raise its anchor and proceed to Finnish territorial waters where it remains under state control[1]. Helsinki Police Department is investigating the incident as aggravated criminal damage, attempted aggravated criminal damage, and aggravated interference with telecommunications[1][3][2]. The inquiry is being conducted in cooperation with Finnish Defence Forces, Customs, and Estonian authorities[1].

items.title: Iran replaces central bank chief as protests spread nationwide

featured_image.name: Protests in Iran spread amid deep discontent over economic duress

items.description:
Demonstrations erupted across Iran for the fourth consecutive day on Tuesday as the national currency collapsed to historic lows, prompting President Masoud Pezeshkian to replace his central bank governor and pledge government action to address mounting economic grievances[1][2][3].

The protests began Sunday when merchants in Tehran's Grand Bazaar shuttered their shops after the rial plunged to approximately 1.42 million against the U.S. dollar, compared to 820,000 a year earlier[1][2]. By Monday, strikes had spread beyond the capital to Isfahan, Shiraz, Kermanshah, Yazd, Zanjan, and Hamadan, with security forces deploying tear gas and, according to unverified reports, live ammunition to disperse crowds[4][5][6].

University students joined the demonstrations Tuesday, with protests reported at more than ten campuses nationwide[1][3][7]. Videos circulating on social media showed students chanting "Death to the dictator," referring to Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, while others tore down signs representing his office at Beheshti University[2][7][8]. The Guild Council of the University of Tehran said six students were detained but later released[4].

items.title: Global stocks surge as emerging markets outpace US

featured_image.name: From the US to China, 2025 a blockbuster year for stock markets

items.description:
Stock markets worldwide capped 2025 with robust gains, as emerging markets outpaced developed peers for the first time in five years and artificial intelligence infrastructure spending drove a shift in technology sector leadership beyond the usual giants.

The MSCI All Country World Index, tracking over 2,500 stocks across developed and emerging markets, rose more than 21% through late December to reach record highs[1][2]. Even more striking, the MSCI ACWI Ex-US index achieved its best performance since the 2009 global financial crisis, climbing approximately 30% as investors diversified away from concentrated U.S. positions[3][4]. By comparison, the S&P 500 gained 18.7% for the year, marking its third consecutive annual advance[5][6].

South Korea's KOSPI index led all major global markets with a stunning 75.6% gain, its strongest annual performance since 1999[7][8]. The rally was powered by semiconductor manufacturers SK Hynix and Samsung Electronics, whose shares surged approximately 280% and 125% respectively on surging demand for high-bandwidth memory chips used in AI systems[7][9].

Latin America emerged as an unexpected star, with Colombia's equity market skyrocketing over 91% to claim the top spot globally, according to data compiled by Morningstar for CNBC[1]. Chile, Peru, Mexico, and Brazil all posted gains exceeding 45%, establishing the region as a standout performer[1]. Analysts attributed Colombia's rally to low initial valuations, improving investor sentiment ahead of presidential elections, and a Colombian peso that appreciated nearly 15% against the dollar[1].

items.title: NASA sets February 2026 for first crewed moon mission in 50 years

featured_image.name: NASA could launch historic Artemis II mission around the moon as early as February 2026

items.description:
For the first time in more than half a century, humans will venture beyond low-Earth orbit when NASA launches its Artemis II mission as early as February 5, 2026[1][2][3][4]. Just months later, in November, the European and Japanese BepiColombo spacecraft will begin its detailed scientific study of Mercury after an eight-year journey through the solar system[5][6][7][8].

The twin milestones mark a renewed era of deep space exploration, with Artemis II paving the way for lunar landings and BepiColombo promising to unlock secrets of the solar system's smallest and least understood planet.

items.title: Gold and copper cap historic year with record gains

featured_image.name: Trump says 50% tariff on copper will begin Aug. 1

items.description:
Gold and copper closed out 2025 with their strongest annual performances in decades, as a convergence of monetary policy shifts, surging industrial demand, and geopolitical uncertainty propelled the metals to unprecedented heights.

Gold climbed more than 64% this year to trade around $4,330 per ounce on Tuesday, marking its largest annual gain since 1979, when the Iranian revolution sent prices soaring[1][2][3]. Copper notched a 41% rise on the London Metal Exchange, its best performance since 2009[4][5], as electrification and artificial intelligence infrastructure drove demand to record levels.

items.title: Harvard physicist says interstellar object may be alien tech

featured_image.name: Hubble observes unusual twin jets from interstellar object 3I/ATLAS as it leaves the solar system

items.description:
Harvard physicist Avi Loeb has intensified his claim that the interstellar visitor 3I/ATLAS may be an alien spacecraft, citing new Hubble Space Telescope images that reveal an unusual dual-jet structure as the object speeds away from Earth.

Observations captured on December 12 and 27 show two distinct jets of material streaming from the object's nucleus, with one pointing toward the Sun and a weaker jet extending in the opposite direction[1][2][3]. As one jet brightens, the other fades in what Loeb describes as a "clean, repeatable and geometrically consistent swap"[4].

Loeb, a Harvard astrophysicist who leads the Galileo Project, has ranked 3I/ATLAS a "four" on his personal scale of zero to ten, where zero represents a natural comet and ten signifies an active alien threat[5][6]. "You can't just say, 'I know the answer' and ignore the anomalies. That's not viable," Loeb said[5][6].

3I/ATLAS, discovered on July 1, 2025, is only the third confirmed interstellar object to visit our solar system, following 'Oumuamua in 2017 and 2I/Borisov in 2019[7][8]. The object passed Earth on December 19 at a safe distance of roughly 170 million miles and is now heading toward Jupiter, where it will make its closest approach on March 16, 2026[5][9].

items.title: Iran suspends work in 21 provinces as protests spread

featured_image.name: Surge of Economic Pain Pushes Iranians to the Streets

items.description: Demonstrations across Iran escalated on Tuesday as university students joined shopkeepers and bazaar merchants in protests sparked by the Iranian rial plunging to a record low of 1.42 million per dollar and inflation surging to 42.2%[1][2][3][4][5]. The unrest, now in its third consecutive day, prompted the government to suspend official work in 21 of the country's 31 provinces[2] and offer a 20-point economic plan[6] in a notable departure from the regime's typically harsh response to dissent.

items.title: Copper surges 41% in 2025 on AI demand, mine disasters

featured_image.name: Copper on pace for best year since 2009 as AI demand, supply fears fuel record price rally

items.description:
Copper has surged to record highs in 2025, posting its strongest annual gain since the financial crisis as artificial intelligence infrastructure drives unprecedented demand while a wave of mine disasters tightens global supply. The industrial metal climbed approximately 41% this year, reaching a record $12,960 per metric ton on the London Metal Exchange on Monday before pulling back slightly[1][2][3][4].

The rally marks the metal's best performance since 2009, when it gained over 140% as economies recovered from the global financial crisis[1][2][3]. As of Tuesday, copper notched its eighth consecutive day of gains, its longest winning streak in eight years[2].
